programmes.show_description: National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
American author Jennifer Niven invites Take Four Books to 'Meet the Newmans' in her newest novel, and shares three works that inspired its creation.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for UK shipping.
BBC Radio 4 presents a selection of news and current affairs, arts and science programmes from the BBC World Service.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for UK shipping.
Bells on Sunday comes from St Nicholas church,  Durweston in Dorset.
In Touch hears about a campaign that aims to help visually impaired people better identify ultra-processed foods, through the use of specialist QR codes.
The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.
Sharon Cornelissen, sociologist and director of housing at the Consumer Federation of America, and cultural historian Matt Houlbrook join Laurie Taylor to talk about gentrification.
Rose Ferraby meets Penny Armstrong and Alan Robertson, whose social enterprise Transition Turriefield helps provide fresh produce on Shetland and trains locals to grow their own.
The latest weather reports and forecast.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
A look at the ethical and religious issues of the week with William Crawley. Jesse Jackson remembered, The Testament of Ann Lee, and Epstein and the popes.
Actor Jemma Redgrave makes the Radio 4 Appeal on behalf of Encephalitis International.
The latest weather reports and forecast.
The news headlines, including a look at the newspapers.
Sunday Worship on this first Sunday in Lent comes from the Metropolitan Cathedral in Liverpool.
In 1938, South African museum curator Marjorie Courtenay-Latimer discovered a fish that was believed to have been extinct for 65 million years.
Tweet of the Day is a series of fascinating stories about birds inspired by their calls, songs and behaviour.
The Sunday papers cover the fallout from Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor's arrest on Thursday over suspicion of misconduct in public office. We discuss with Jennie Bond and Andrew Marr.
Roula Khalaf, journalist and editor, shares the eight tracks, book and luxury item she would take with her if cast away to a desert island. With Lauren Laverne.
Alice has a suggestion to put to Rex, and Josh drops a bombshell.
Californian governor and Trump's political nemesis.
3/6. In a first for the show, the audience manage to get on the scoreboard.
The latest weather forecast.
Radio 4's look at the week's big stories from both home and around the world.

...Exporting the Housing Crisis. In London, mounting housing pressures have led some councils to place homeless families outside the capital - in some cases more than 250 miles away, in County Durham.
Which colourful plants thrive in shady, chalky soil? How can I reach into borders without treading on emerging plants? Can leaving weeds help veg crops? The GQT panel answers all.
John Yorke concludes his exploration of Margaret Mitchell's epic Civil War romance, Gone with the Wind, and considers the book's complex legacy in today's world.
Set against the epic backdrop of the American Civil War, an iconic and stunning tale of love and loss, of a nation divided and a people forever changed. Dramatised by Rachel Joyce.
Bestselling author John Lanchester speaks to Take Four Books about his latest novel, Look What You Made Me Do, and its connection to three other works.
8/13. Paul Gambaccini is in the chair as the ultimate music quiz returns, with questions on music of all varieties and eras.
In November 1975, the leaders of six industrialised nations met for a summit to solve an economic crisis. It marked the birth of the G7 forum.
George Szirtes on Poems on the Underground; Iryna Starovoyt on titan of Ukrainian literature 19th-century poet Taras Shevchenko; Katie Clarke of The Reader on poetry and dementia.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for UK shipping.
The latest weather reports and forecast.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
Andrew Peach presents a weekly selection of the best bits of audio across the BBC.
Chelsea's getting more hopeful about her business plans, and David is reluctantly learning how to recruit volunteers.
Hilik Magnus is a world-renowned search and rescue specialist. Even now, at 76, he cannot stop saving people. Contains strong language.
A series of personal reflections on power.
Michael Rosen talks to Sophia Smith Galer about the languages we're losing. She's found that by the end of this century half of the world's 7000 languages will have disappeared.
Kirsty Lang on Reverend Jesse Jackson, abortion campaigner Diane Munday, the French clown Philippe Gaulier and charity founder Lady Jean Wilson.
Regulators are warning claims management firms acting for customers mis-sold car finance not to overcharge when claimants want to cancel.
Actor Jemma Redgrave makes the Radio 4 Appeal on behalf of Encephalitis International.
Four years since the beginning of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, soldiers and civilians share their stories of grief, resistance, and desire for peace.
Radio 4's Sunday night political discussion programme.
Misha Glenny and guests discuss the short, brilliant life of one of the most celebrated Romantic poets and the works of his most intensely creative year from autumn 1818.
In the award winning writer Tahmima Anam's new story Shafiq learns an unexpected lesson during his sister's opulent wedding celebrations. The reader is Gavi Singh Chera.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
True stories of what Yellow, one of Coldplay's most iconic songs, means to people 25 years on from its release.
Bells on Sunday comes from St Nicholas church,  Durweston in Dorset.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for UK shipping.
BBC Radio 4 presents a selection of news and current affairs, arts and science programmes from the BBC World Service.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
Kirsty Lang on Reverend Jesse Jackson, abortion campaigner Diane Munday, the French clown Philippe Gaulier and charity founder Lady Jean Wilson.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for UK shipping.
A spiritual comment and prayer to start the day with Paul Kerensa.
The government's announced a new 10 year plan for controlling deer numbers in England. It estimates 1/3 of  woodlands are damaged by deer.
The latest weather reports and forecasts for farmers.
News and current affairs, including Sports Desk, Weather and Thought for the Day.
Professor Sir Lawrence Freedman on war strategy; Rebecca Newell on the art of WW2; and Jane Rogoyska's book about a Parisian hotel hosting refugees and Nazis. Adam Rutherford hosts.
Matthew Hyndman, also known as Matty from the BBC One series The Traitors, tells Rachel Burden about how he's sharing his passion for hillwalking.
Women's voices and women's lives - topical conversations to inform, challenge and inspire.
2/3. Sifting through the dust, Mark Miodownik discovers the toxins polluting our living spaces.
...Transformation After Trauma. 1/5. Leading forensic psychiatrist Gwen Adshead reflects on her work with survivors of trauma.
The latest national and international news from BBC Radio 4.
News and discussion of consumer affairs.
The latest weather forecast.
News, analysis and comment from BBC Radio 4.
6/11. Lucy's on her lunchbreak when she tries her first scratchcard - but soon her gambling is out of control.
Chelsea's getting more hopeful about her business plans, and David is reluctantly learning how to recruit volunteers.
5/6. Richard Herring's comedy about family. Starring Alison Steadman, Phil Davies and Richard Herring. Ian recuperates with the help of nostalgic children's television theme tunes.
John Yorke concludes his exploration of Margaret Mitchell's epic Civil War romance, Gone with the Wind, and considers the book's complex legacy in today's world.
Crime writer Martin Edwards and the sociologist, bioethicist and comedian Tom Shakespeare talk about books they love with Harriett Gilbert.
Greg Jenner is joined by historian Dr David Veevers and comedian and quizzer Paul Sinha to learn all about the global history of spices and the spice trade.

...Exporting the Housing Crisis. In London, mounting housing pressures have led some councils to place homeless families outside the capital - in some cases more than 250 miles away, in County Durham.
1/6. Jay Rayner and the panel are at University College London. Joining Jay are Melissa Thompson, Jocky Petrie, Tim Anderson and, on home turf, materials expert Dr Zoe Laughlin.
News and current affairs, reporting on breaking stories and summing up the day's headlines.
National and international news from BBC Radio 4.
4/6. Players take on subjects like Mrs. Bennett from Pride and Prejudice, answering the big question is Mr. Collins a vicar or a rector?
Susan and Helen are on a quest to find new staff for the dairy, and Chris and Hannah despair for the future of Ambridge Cricket.
Live magazine programme on the worlds of arts, literature, film, media and music.
3/10. The back-story of the Middle East conflict, explored by leading experts. Part 3: early Zionism, Palestine in late Ottoman times and Great Power interest in the region.
Marnie Chesterton and guests explore the chemistry of barbecue and explore how cooking over fire helped shape human evolution.
Professor Sir Lawrence Freedman on war strategy; Rebecca Newell on the art of WW2; and Jane Rogoyska's book about a Parisian hotel hosting refugees and Nazis. Adam Rutherford hosts.
Matthew Hyndman, also known as Matty from the BBC One series The Traitors, tells Rachel Burden about how he's sharing his passion for hillwalking.
In depth reporting, intelligent analysis and breaking news from a global perspective.
1/5. A love story based on the lives of the author's great-grandparents, who married in 1878. Cardiff girl Ellen meets Samuel, a ship's cook from Barbados.
6/8. Ground-breaking action-thriller, adapted from the novel by James Swallow. Sam and Sarah pressure Kobin for more intel. Whilst Stone pays a deadly visit to an Oil Rig.
News, views and features on today's stories in Parliament.
